concept.title: Document modification [Beta]
concept.shortdesc: Query may be used to efficiently modify documents conforming to a specific criteria. This is part of the DML (Data Manipulation Language) and is considered beta at the time of writing.

messagepanel.howtoavoid: Executing a DML N1QL statement may result in modification of data even if the actual statement fails to execute. Application-side retry logic should take this into account when doing something like SET field=field+1 for example.

conbody.section:
UPDATEDocuments may be updated selectively based on a specific set of constraints using the UPDATE statement. You can update documents based on their document ID or by a secondary attribute.
The following snippet updates the sale_price of every product type document to be 25% off the original price. It also makes use of the RETURNING keyword to also return relevant information from within the document itself.
query = N1QLQuery( 'UPDATE default ' 'SET sale_price=ROUND(price-(price * 0.25), 2) ' 'WHERE type=$1' 'RETURNING name, price, sale_price', 'product' )
for row in cb.n1ql_query(query): print '{0} WAS: {1:2}. NOW ONLY {2:2}'.format( row['name'], row['price'], row['sale_price'])The UPDATE keyword can also be used for in-place updates of specific document IDs using the USE KEYS specifier. The following example updates a single field in a document, specified by its document ID:query = N1QLQuery( 'UPDATE default USE KEYS $keys SET description=$desc', keys=['utilikilt1_speaker'], desc='Use this handy utilikilt as a fashion accessory or in the garage, and lets ' ) cb.n1ql_query(query).execute()

DELETEDocuments may also be removed using a syntax similar to UPDATE. Like UPDATE, the DELETE statement is powerful as it allows deletion of items by using secondary criteria. The example below removes all documents which have a type of productmeta = cb.n1ql_query( N1QLQuery('DELETE from default WHERE type=$1', 'product') ).execute().meta print 'Deleted {0} items!'.format(meta['metrics'].get('mutationCount', 0))
